titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Grants, Accession 2015:115 FA1321
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-10-01 04:47:03 UTC.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Grants, Accession 2015:115

physdesc.extent: 49 containers - 42 letter-sized document containers, 3 legal-sized document containers, and 1 oversize document container box (4 document containers of separated materials)

did.langmaterial: Most materials are in English, but the collection also includes Spanish, French, Polish, Portuguese, Chinese, Hungarian, and Indonesian materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Each folder title typically includes (1.) Name of Grantee; (2.) Project Name; and (3.) Grant Program Action Number. The Ford Foundation Program Area (ex. Peace and Social Justice, Media, Arts, and Culture, Overseas, etc.) associated with each particular grant, along with further description of the types of materials, can be found in the additional description note.

Each Ford Foundation Grant and the corresponding Grant File is identified by a unique Program Action (PA) number. PA numbers begin with the year a grant was made (2-digits), followed by a sequential number within that year (4-digits).

For example: PA 55-0123 was the 123rd grant made in the year 1955. PA numbers are often typed or handwritten on Ford documents in the following format: 55-123 (year)-(####). However, the Ford Foundation's grants database (LINKS) uses an 8-digit format for PA numbers: 05500123 (0YY#####).
Beginning in the 1970s the 4th digit in the 8-digit PA number was used to encode at least three different types of Ford grants:
1. 0YY5#### = Delegated Authority Grants (DAG) / Delegated Authority Projects (DAP)
After the year 2000 a "1" is used as the first digit in the 8-digit PA number to signify the 21st century. For example, the 123rd grant made in 2012 would be PA number 11200123.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains press clippings, photographs, slides, digital media, brochures, and other ephemera related to various Ford Foundation grants from the 1990s to the 2000s. These materials were retained as part of a grant's attachments file. More information about individual grants can be found in the Ford Foundation's microfilmed grant records collections.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For further descriptions of Ford Foundation grants in this collection, please refer to the following findng aids (arranged alphabetically):

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Special format items have been separated from the body of the collection and assigned a unique separation number, as noted. Requests to access open special formats should reference the unique separation number.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2015 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2015:115

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.
